bibl.title: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Domingo F. Ramos, March 18, 1941

div1.p: Cooke endorses Hench's findings concerning the actual sites of Camp Lazear and the Yellow Fever Hospital. Cooke expresses hope that the site will be preserved as a fitting memorial to the conquest of yellow fever by Finlay, Reed and his colleagues.

div1.head: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Domingo F. Ramos, March 18, 1941
div1.opener:
COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA
STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
LEXINGTON-ROCKBRIDGE HEALTH DEPARTMENT
LEXINGTON, VIRGINIA
March 18th, 1941
To His Excellency Dr. Domingo Romos
Minister of National Defense
Government of Cuba
Havana, Cuba
Thru.- Dr. Philip S. Hench
div1.p:
After a careful perusal of the Documentary summary
prepared by Dr. Philip S. Hench in regard to the historical
sites of Camp Lazear and the Yellow Fever hospital. I am
convinced that the facts are essentially correct and that
arguments worked out in support of these facts are most con-
clusive. At the time of these experiments I was serving at
Columbia Barracks as Acting Asst. Surgeon, U.S. Army and was
permitted to take a small part in bringing out the facts
relating to the non infectiousness of fomites.

The probability that the site will be preserved as a
fitting memorial to the conquest of yellow fever by Finlay,
and by Reed and his colleagues, who are among the world's
greatest benefactors, will I am sure, be a source of real
satisfaction and a sympathetic bond of union between our
governments.
